#Text=Interview with Navdeep Gill , City Council candidate for Wards 2 & 6 in Brampton , Canada
#Text=Friday , September 22 , 2006
#Text=Candidate Navdeep Gill .
#Text=The upcoming 2006 Brampton municipal election , to be held November 13 , features an array of candidates looking to represent their wards in city council or the council of the Peel Region .
#Text=Wikinews contributor Nick Moreau contacted many of the candidates , including Navdeep Gill , asking them to answer common questions sent in an email .
#Text=This ward 's incumbent is John A. Hutton ; also challenging Hutton is Derrick Coke , Jim Howell , Mathew Mburu Njenga , Joyce Rodriguez , and Doug Whillans .
#Text=Interview
#Text=Q : List the three most important issues in your campaign .
#Text=A : 1 ) Addressing council 's management of development in Brampton ;
#Text=( 2 ) Addressing the concerns of our residents regarding their quality of life ;
#Text=( 3 ) Addressing environmental and gridlock concerns .
#Text=Q : What one election issue do you feel is most relevant to your ward in this election ?
#Text=A : Most important is to manage and tackle issues that branch out from the recent development and influx of population that has taken place in the past three years .
#Text=Q : What qualities or experiences do you possess , that make you more desirable than the incumbent ?

#Text=A : Brampton residents need to know that their quality of life is being looked after and addressed by individuals who are educated in policy and government ; individuals who have the knowledge to actively pursue their vision of Brampton in the coming years .
#Text=Q : Why do you want to represent your ward on council ?
#Text=A : I want to engage my community residents and I want to become an active member in a position where I can influence change and make a positive contribution for all residents
#Text=Q : Of the decisions made by council since the last election , which one would you have changed , and why ?
#Text=A : I would have worked harder to ensure that infrastructure was addressed and being put into place before new developments were completed .
#Text=The lack of management in this area has placed a greater tax burden on residents to cover costs .
#Text=Q : How are you currently involved in the community ?
#Text=A : I am working alongside Model United Nations to raise political and diplomatic awareness amongst the youth .
#Text=Engaging the youth has always been a strong concern for me .
#Text=Q : Much of Brampton 's existing council is quite seasoned in the civic political process .
#Text=What could you bring to the table as a " rookie " , above and beyond the current roster of councillors ?
#Text=A : I would respond to the changing needs of these changing wards .
#Text=A fresh perspective is needed for the very reason that these wards are headed towards a fresh direction .
#Text=The issues we are facing now and will be facing in the future are very different from the issues faced in the 1980s and the 1990s .

#Text=We have a changing environment , an influx in population , increasing levels of multiculturalism , and a high level of growth and most importantly , a large number of growing youth , who are the future of our City and our wards .
#Text=Q : The Rose Theatre recently launched .
#Text=What are your thoughts on this facility ?
#Text=Have you had a chance to tour it yet ?
#Text=A : So far business has been good with the Rose Theatre as local Brampton residents and residents beyond our borders are taking advantage of the entertainment shows .
#Text=Of course the long-term success of the theatre is to be seen .
#Text=My hope is that it will continue to provide successful shows as it has the potential to bring a lot of investment into our city .
#Text=Yes I have visited the theatre .
#Text=Q : The province has strongly encouraged the development of high-density residences near the downtown .
#Text=Do these buildings fit in with your vision of the downtown ?
#Text=How much say should other levels of government have in urban planning ?
#Text=A : The choice belongs to the residents and my vision will coincide with the vision of those I represent .
#Text=Q : How do you feel about Brampton 's rate of expansion ?
#Text=Council recently capped the annual amount of new development ; do you agree completely with this decision , would you have slowed development even further , or not have imposed a cap at all ?
#Text=A : It is good that Brampton slowed it down , as the process was out of control to begin with .
#Text=Development is good , but only if it is managed well .
#Text=Brampton should have expanded in increments instead of sporadic developments springing up in all corners .

#Text=This has resulted in gaps leaving residents with a much larger tax burden to fill , rather than the lower costs that would have been achieved if Brampton had managed their expansion more efficiently .
#Text=Q : Why should businesses be attracted to locating in Brampton ?
#Text=A : We are still a young city with much potential .
#Text=We have a skilled population and any business would find great success for their future prospects .
#Text=Q : How could Brampton further itself in attracting corporate investment ?
#Text=A : By showcasing a strong and efficient reputation as a city that is capable of effective management .
#Text=Q : Why have you chosen to involve yourself in the political process ?

#Text=A : As a political science graduate I have long since targeted a profession in the political process , where I can use my strengths and my knowledge to help represent the views of my residents .
#Text=The reason why I have chosen to join Council now is because I strongly feel there is a need for a committed and active representative .
#Text=A fresh voice is needed .
#Text=Q : What does Brampton mean to you ?
#Text=A : As a long-time resident of Brampton , it has meant a safe and clean neighbourhood where people can raise their families and enjoy a good quality of life .
#Text=Working hard in council for me would be a way to help ensure that this sort of environment continues for future generations .
